titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Grants, Accession 2015:094 FA1409
titlestmt.author: Katie Martin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-07-14 00:00:11 -0400.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection contains one series: Grant Files.
The material is arranged in order of Program Action (PA) number (loosely chronological by year).

Each Ford Foundation Grant and the corresponding Grant File is identified by a unique Program Action (PA) number. PA numbers begin with the year a grant was made (2-digits), followed by a sequential number within that year (4-digits).

For example: PA 55-0123 was the 123rd grant made in the year 1955. PA numbers are often typed or handwritten on Ford documents in the following format: 55-123 (year)-(####). However, the Ford Foundation's grants database (LINKS) uses an 8-digit format for PA numbers: 05500123 (0YY#####).
In some cases, the 4th digit in the 8-digit PA number was used to encode at least three different types of Ford grants:
1. 0YY5#### = Delegated Authority Grants (DAG) / Delegated Authority Projects (DAP)
Individual folders are typically arranged reverse chronologically.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Most of the material in this collection has been microfilmed and corresponds with material found in the following Ford Foundation microfilm collections:

(Note: When searching for corresponding microfilm material, Program Action (PA) numbers in this collection are typed or handwritten on Ford documents in the following format: 55-123 (year)-(####). However, the Ford Foundation's grants database (LINKS) uses an 8-digit format for PA numbers: 05500123 (0YY#####). The materials in the microfilm collections are searchable in the 8-digit format)
FA732A Ford Foundation records, Grants, A-B
FA732B Ford Foundation records, Grants, C-D
FA732D Ford Foundation records, Grants, H-K
FA732E Ford Foundation records, Grants, L-N
FA732F Ford Foundation records, Grants, O-R
FA732G Ford Foundation records, Grants, S-Thel
FA732H Ford Foundation records, Grants, Them-Tw
FA732I Ford Foundation records, Grants, U-Z
More information relating to individual grants can be found in these collections' additional description notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains grant approval letters, correspondence, financial information, reports, and clippings related to Ford Foundation grants from 1936-1977.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Most folders contain the following note from March 1980:

This is a grant* made during the period 1936-1952. The following documents are the only records known for this grant action. The files kept for grants given at this time were maintained by the Treasurer in alphabetic order by institution. This grant file, like the others of this period, was assigned a Program Action (PA) number under which it has been microfilmed.
In some cases the "grant" was only a donation to a particular charity, society, or cause.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2015 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2015:094.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note from cross reference sheet - (Formerly A-835) The early grants to MIT overlap extensively. Several reports that could not be located in this file may be found in others. This file covers the years 1951-1956 (with correspondence to 1967) while the subsequent grant PA 56-104 covers the period 1956-1977.
